TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed beforefieldinit InitializeEventArgs extends System.EventArgs
Public NotInheritable Class InitializeEventArgs Inherits EventArgs
public ref class InitializeEventArgs sealed : EventArgs

Docs.summary: Used to set of an InfoPath form template hosted in the control.

remarks.para: For more information about using query and input parameters, see How To: Use Query Parameters to Invoke Browser-Enabled InfoPath Forms.

example.para: In the following example, the property is used in the event of the control to create a name/value pair indicating the department name.
example.code: Protected Sub XmlFormView1_Initialize(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As Microsoft.Office.InfoPath.Server.Controls.InitializeEventArgs) Handles XmlFormView1.Initialize e.InputParameters("Dept") = "Accounting" End Sub
example.para: To use this input parameter in form code, use the property of the object available in the namespace. For example, the value set in the XmlFormView1 initialization event is used to set a field's value in the form.
example.code: Public Sub FormEvents_Loading(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As LoadingEventArgs) Dim MyNav As XPathNavigator MyNav = Me.MainDataSource.CreateNavigator() MyNav.SelectSingleNode("/my:myFields/my:field2", Me.NamespaceManager).SetValue(e.InputParameters("Dept").ToString()) End Sub
example.para: To use this input parameter in form code, use the property of the object available in the namespace. For example, the value set in the XmlFormView1 initialization event is used to set a field's value in the form.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property InputParameters As Dictionary(Of String, String)

public: property System::Collections::Generic::Dictionary<System::String ^, System::String ^> ^ InputParameters { System::Collections::Generic::Dictionary<System::String ^, System::String ^> ^ get(); };

Docs.summary: Sets name/value pairs for use as custom parameters that can be used in the form being initialized in the control.

remarks.para: For more information about query and input parameters, see How To: Use Query Parameters to Invoke Browser-Enabled InfoPath Forms.

example.para: In the following example, the property is used in the event of the control to create a name/value pair indicating the department name.
example.code: Protected Sub XmlFormView1_Initialize(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As Microsoft.Office.InfoPath.Server.Controls.InitializeEventArgs) Handles XmlFormView1.Initialize e.InputParameters("Dept") = "Accounting" End Sub
example.para: To use this input parameter in form code, use the property of the object available in the namespace. For example, the value set in the XmlFormView1 initialization event is used to set a field's value in the form.
example.code: Public Sub FormEvents_Loading(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As LoadingEventArgs) Dim MyNav As XPathNavigator MyNav = Me.MainDataSource.CreateNavigator() MyNav.SelectSingleNode("/my:myFields/my:field2", Me.NamespaceManager).SetValue(e.InputParameters("Dept").ToString()) End Sub
example.para: To use this input parameter in form code, use the property of the object available in the namespace. For example, the value set in the XmlFormView1 initialization event is used to set a field's value in the form.
